Borrowed from Middle French cursif, from Medieval Latin cursīvus, from Latin cursus.

The Ancient Greek term was influenced by Hebrew חרם‎ (herem), leading to the sense of "accursed," especially in Ecclesiastical writers.

syn: unstable, unsteady, impulsive, moody, quicksilver, giddy, mutable, fluid, whimsical, excitable, fluctuating, erratic, inconstant, inconsistent, vacillating, protean, kaleidoscopic, capricious, wavering, temperamental, ever-changing, flighty, wayward, unpredictable, variable, fickle, changeable

From Latin fīdūciārius (“held in trust”), from fīdūcia (“trust”).

syn: reprove, give someone a piece of one's mind, upbraid, berate, criticize, censure, read someone the Riot Act, castigate, scold, chide, haul over the coals, admonish, remonstrate with, chastise, lambaste, pull up, take to task, reproach
etym: From Middle English rebuken, from Anglo-Norman rebuker (“to beat back, repel”), from re- + Old French *buker, buchier, buschier (“to strike, hack down, chop”), from busche (“wood”), from Vulgar Latin buska (“wood, grove”), from Frankish *busc, *busk (“grove”), from Proto-Germanic *buskaz (“bush”); equivalent to re- +‎ bush.

syn: satirical

When eaten, it would cause the eater's face to contort in a look resembling scorn (generally followed by death)[2]. It might also be related to σαίρω (saírō, “I grin”).

syn: statement, attestation, contention, claim, allegation, avowal, plea, charge, submission, declaration, sworn statement

Cognate to fidelity and faith (same Latin root), but not to affirm (shared Latin ad- prefix, but different Latin and Proto-Indo-European roots).

syn: course, course outline, course of study, educational programme, programme of study

syn: supernatural being, manifestation, vision, spectre, phantom, apparition, spirit, poltergeist, presence, shadow
etym: First attested 1513, in a Middle Scots translation of the Aeneid (book 10 of the Eneados of Gawin Douglas): "Nor ȝit na vayn wrathys nor gaiſtis quent / Thi char conſtrenyt bakwart forto went" (c. X, ln. 81-82; "Nor yet no vain wraiths nor quaint ghosts / constrained Thy chariot to go backward"), "Syklyke as that, thai ſay, in diuers placis / The wraithis walkis of goiſtis that ar ded" (c. XI, ln. 95-96; "Such as that, they say, in diverse places / The wraiths walk of ghosts that are dead"), "Thydder went this wrath or ſchaddo of Ene, / That ſemyt, all abaſyt, faſt to fle" (c. XI, ln. 129-130; "Thither went this wraith or shade of Ene, / That seemed, all abased, fast to flee").

zh_Hans: （艺术作品的）选集；（常指）精选集
syn: treasury, anthology, digest, compilation
etym: Borrowed from Ancient Greek ἀνθολογία (anthología, “flower-gathering”), from ἀνθολογέω (anthologéō, “I gather flowers”), from ἄνθος (ánthos, “flower”) + λέγω (légō, “I gather, pick up, collect”), coined by Meleager of Gadara circa 60 BCE, originally as Στέφανος (στέφανος (stéphanos, “garland”)) to describe a collection of poetry, later retitled anthology – see Greek Anthology. Anthologiai were collections of small Greek poems and epigrams, because in Greek culture the flower symbolized the finer sentiments that only poetry can express.

syn: unavoidable, unstoppable, inescapable, inevitable, irrevocable
etym: From Middle French inexorable, from Latin inexōrābilis (“relentless, inexorable”) (or directly from the Latin word), from in- (prefix meaning ‘not’) + exōrābilis (“that may be moved or persuaded by entreaty; exorable”).[1] Exōrābilis is derived from exōrāre[2] (from exōrō (“to persuade, win over; to beg, entreat, plead”), from ex- (prefix meaning ‘out of’) + ōrō (“to beg, entreat, plead, pray; to deliver a speech, orate”), from ōs (“mouth”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₃éh₁os (“mouth”)) + -bilis (suffix forming adjectives indicating a capacity or worth of being acted upon).
English Wikipedia has an article on:fortnightWikipedia

syn: rum (obsolete, quirk, oddity, peculiarity, outlier, rarity, aberration, odd fish (idiomatic), variation, aberrant, irregularity, abnormality    [WS], farlie (obsolete, incongruity, slang), British dialect), deviance, divergence, anomaly, strange fish (idiomatic), deviant, queerness, deviation, exception, freak, abnormality, departure, weirdness, inconsistency, strangeness    [WS], unusualness

syn: ratify, agree to, assent to, confirm, endorse, defend, maintain, approve of, sanction, consent to, support, approve
etym: Alteration influenced by Medieval Latin indorsare of Middle English endosse, from Old French endosser (“to put on back”), from Latin dossum, alternative form of dorsum (“back”),[1] from which also dorsal (“of the back”). That is, the ‘r’ was dropped in Latin dossum, which developed into Old French and then Middle English endosse, and then the ‘r’ was re-introduced into English via the Medieval Latin indorsare, which had retained the ‘r’. Note that the alternative spelling indorse also uses the initial ‘i’ from Latin (in-, rather than en-), but this form is now rare.

Akin to Old High German magan, megin (“power, might, main”), Old English mæġen (“might, main”), Old High German magan, mugan (“to be powerful, able”), Old English magan (“to be able”). Cognate with Portuguese desmaiar (“to faint”). See also Portuguese esmagar, Spanish amagar. More at main, may.

syn: integral, permanent, essential, inherent, built-in, congenital, inborn, inbuilt, constitutional, ingrained, ineradicable, inwrought (figurative), inbred, radical, infused, intrinsic, immanent, innate, deep-rooted, native, ineffaceable, natural, inseparable, indelible, instilled

From Ancient Greek μελαγχολικός (melankholikós, “atrabilious, impulsive, of atrabilious or melancholic temperament”), from μελαγχολία (melankholía, “melancholy”).

hypo: trek, hike, excursion, wayfare, constitutional, raik (British dialect), expedition, tour, drive, yomp (UK), peregrination, voyage, flight, travel, jaunt, exodus, course, ramble, hegira, walk    [WS], ride, pilgrimage, outing, trudge, tramp (New Zealand), tab (UK)

zh_Hans: （尤指基于种族或性别原因）隔离并差别对待

etym: From Latin sēgregātus, perfect passive participle of sēgregō (“I separate”), from sē- (“apart”) + gregō (“I flock or group”), from grex (“flock”). Compare gregarious, aggregate.

syn: appropriateness, decency, modesty, respectability, correctness, good manners, civility, demureness, rectitude, politeness, courtesy

zh_Hans: 惯犯;但累犯;再犯;累犯;累犯,惯犯
etym: From French récidivisme, from Latin recidīvus (“returning, recurring”). Compare recidivous, -ism.

syn: fire up, madden, inflame, anger, make someone's blood boil, send into a rage, stir up, incense
etym: From Medieval Latin infuriatus (“enraged”), past participle of infurio (“to enrage”), from Latin furia (“rage, fury, frenzy”), perhaps via Italian infuriato.

syn: falter, teeter, be indecisive, be in two minds, waver, be ambivalent, be undecided, oscillate, vacillate, change one's mind, be unsure, fluctuate
etym: Variant of didder, from Middle English didderen (“to tremble”), ultimately from Proto-Germanic *titrōną, whence also derived Old High German zittarōn (German zittern) and Old Norse titra (Faroese titra, Icelandic titra).

syn: stock-still, motionless, sleeping, still, immobile, stationary, dormant, static
etym: From French inerte, from Latin iners (“inactive, inert”).

zh_Hans: （尤指出现新进步和大变革的）时代，纪元，时期
syn: aeon, period, span, time, age
etym: From Medieval Latin epocha, from Ancient Greek ἐποχή (epokhḗ, “a check, cessation, stop, pause, epoch of a star, i.e., the point at which it seems to halt after reaching the highest, and generally the place of a star; hence, a historical epoch”), from ἐπέχω (epékhō, “I hold in, check”), from ἐπι- (epi-, “upon”) + ἔχω (ékhō, “I have, hold”).

zh_Hans: 欢乐的，愉快的；无忧无虑的
syn: untroubled, indifferent, casual, thoughtless, uncaring, unconcerned, careless, unworried
etym: From Middle English blithe, from Old English blīþe (“blithe, joyous, cheerful, pleasant; gracious, well-disposed, friendly, kind; agreeable, willing; quiet, peaceful, gentle”), from Proto-Germanic *blīþiz (“mild, pleasing, friendly”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰlī- (“light, pleasant, fine”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰel- (“to shine”). Cognate Scots blithe (“joyous, cheerful, happy, well-pleased”), North Frisian blid (“happy, glad”), Saterland Frisian bliede (“happy, joyous, blithe”), West Frisian bliid (“glad, happy, joyful, joyous”), Dutch blijde, blij (“blithe, happy, joyous, glad”), Afrikaans bly (“happy”), German dialectal blid, blied (“glad, happy, cheerful”), Danish blid (“gentle”), Icelandic blíður (“gentle, kind, friendly, mild”). Related to bliss.

zh_Hans: （通常指人的外表或行为）冷峻的，阴沉的，不苟言笑的
syn: frowning, morose, unsmiling, unfriendly, grim, gruff, uncommunicative, gloomy, unsympathetic, stony, grave, surly, mean-looking, poker-faced, austere, serious, sour, forbidding, sullen, disapproving, dismal, solemn, sober, severe, sombre
etym:
From Scots dour, from Latin dūrus (“hard, stern”), possibly via Middle Irish dúr.
Compare French dur, German Dauer, Italian duro, Portuguese duro, Romanian dur, Spanish duro. Doublet of dure.

See manual, and capable.

syn: same-sex, lesbigay, homosexual, queer (sometimes pejorative), lesbian

Equivalent to homo- +‎ -sexual.

etym: From Middle English, from Old French, from Latin dormiēns, present participle of dormiō (“I sleep”).

syn: lecture, censure, read someone the Riot Act, chide, scold, rebuke, remonstrate with, chastise, lambaste, give someone a piece of one's mind, pull up, take to task, reproach, upbraid, berate, haul over the coals, reprove, criticize, admonish
etym: Early 17th cent., borrowed from Latin castīgātus, past participle of castīgō (“I reprove”), from castus (“pure, chaste”), from Proto-Indo-European *kesa (“cut”)[1][2]. Doublet of chastise, taken through Old French. See also chaste.

syn: underage, adolescent, pubescent, teenage, teenaged, prepubescent, junior
etym: A juvenile female (adjective sense 1) – a young Aka girl – from the Central African Republic

zh_Hans: 亲密的；有性关系的；宜于密切关系的
syn: bosom, favourite, special, devoted, familiar, confidential, constant, firm, boon, cherished, faithful, fast, dear
etym: From Latin intimare (“to put or bring into, to impress, to make familiar”), from intimus (“inmost, innermost, most intimate”), superlative of intus (“within”), from in (“in”); see interior.

syn: inexact, false, untrue, off target, inaccurate, in error, invalid, not accurate, imprecise, fallacious, incorrect, not exact, wide of the mark, mistaken
etym: From Old French and Latin erroneus

ko: (동식물에게 생긴 아주 보기 싫은) 이상 성장물[혹], 사마귀
syn: outgrowth, knob, lump, protrusion, swelling, nodule, protuberance
etym: From Middle English, early 15th century, in sense “(action of) growing out (of something else)”. Borrowed from Latin excrescentia (“abnormal growths”), from excrescentem, from excrēscere, from ex- (“out”) (English ex-) + crēscere (“to grow”) (English crescent). Sense of “abnormal growth” from 1570s, from earlier excrescency (1540s in this sense).[1]

zh_Hans: （尤指气体或其他物质）有毒的，有害的
syn: virulent, deadly, toxic
etym: From Latin noxius (“hurtful, injurious”), from noxa (“hurt, injury”), from nocere (“to hurt, injure”); see nocent.

zh_Hans: 令人费解的事物，令人困惑的事物
syn: conundrum, question, quandary, unsolved problem, a closed book, problem, question mark, puzzle, paradox, riddle
etym: From Latin aenigma (“riddle”), being derived itself from the Ancient Greek verbal noun αἴνιγμα (aínigma, “dark saying, speaking in riddles”).

zh_Hans: 特种部队；特殊兵种；军（团）
syn: battery, group, unit, battalion, company, squad, cohort, commando, corps, outfit, section, squadron, band, force, contingent, troop, garrison, detachment, regiment, division, platoon
etym: From French corps d'armée (literally “army body”), from Latin corpus (“body”). Doublet of corpse and corpus. See also English riff.

zh_Hans: 歪歪斜斜地疾行；横冲直撞
syn: incline, careen, slope, be at an angle, angle, pitch, list, bank, cock, heel, bend, camber, cant, dip, slant, tip, bevel
etym: Late 16th century, from French carene (“keel”), from Genoese Ligurian carena, from Latin carina (“keel of a ship”).

syn: unfruitful, waste, desert, sterile, desolate, arid, uncultivatable, infertile
etym: From Middle English barein, barain, from Old French baraigne, baraing (“sterile; barren”), of obscure origin; probably from a Germanic language, perhaps Frankish *bar (“bare; barren”), from Proto-Germanic *bazaz (“bare”). More at bare.

zh_Hans: （尤指宗教或法律上）为（某人）解罪；赦免（某人）的罪；宣告（某人）无罪；免除（某人）的责任
syn: discharge, vindicate, exculpate, acquit
etym: First attested in the early 15th Century. From Middle English absolven, from Latin absolvere, present active infinitive of absolvō (“set free, acquit”), from ab (“away from”) + solvō (“loosen, free, release”).

syn: enthral, transfix, delight, enchant, ravish, entrance, spellbind, fascinate, hold spellbound, mesmerize, seduce, beguile, enrapture, hypnotize, charm
etym: From Middle English bewicchen; equivalent to be- +‎ witch.

syn: hurtful, deleterious, damaging, dangerous, detrimental
etym: From Middle English injurious, from Anglo-Norman enjurius, from Latin iniūriōsus; analysable as injury +‎ -ous.

syn: piercing, screeching, stentorian, raucous, shrill, rasping, grating, loud, ear-piercing, rough, jarring
etym: From French strident, from Latin strīdēns, present active participle of strīdō.

syn: promoter, supporter, proponent, upholder, backer, exponent, patron, protector
etym: Borrowed from Old French advocat, from Latin advocātus (past participle of advocāre (“to call for”)), a calque of Ancient Greek παράκλητος (paráklētos) (whence English paraclete). Doublet of advoke, avouch, and avow.

zh_Hans: 单色的；单色光的；单频的；单能的
etym: From mono- +‎ chromatic, mono- from Ancient Greek μόνος (mónos, “alone, only, sole, single”), chromatic from Ancient Greek χρῶμα (khrôma, “color”).

syn: the honest truth, the whole truth, gospel truth, the naked truth, God's truth
etym: Borrowing from Anglo-Norman verité or Middle French verité, from Old French verité, from Latin vēritās, from the adjective vērus (“true”).

zh_Hans: （文章或讲话的）含意，弦外之音；（事件或情况的）蕴含意义
syn: whisper, murmur, mutter
etym: under- +‎ tone

syn: trusty, hard-working, unswerving, steadfast, unfaltering, firm, unhesitating, unwavering, resolute, dependable, dedicated, vigorous, devoted, committed, redoubtable, faithful, stable, loyal, steady, constant, reliable
etym: From Scots stalwart, from Middle English stal-worth (“physically strong, hardy, robust; brave, courageous”), from Old English stǣlwierþe (“able to stand in good stead, serviceable”),[1] probably from staþol (“establishment; foundation”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *steh₂- (“to stand (up)”)) or stǣl (“place; condition, stead”) + -wierþe (“suffix meaning ‘able to, capable of’”) (probably ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *wert- (“to rotate, turn”)).

zh_Hans: （为给伤口止血或防止感染而）烙，烧灼
syn: sear, singe, scorch
etym: From Middle French cauteriser, from Late Latin cauterizō (“to burn with a hot iron”), from Ancient Greek καυτηριάζω (kautēriázō, “to brand”), from καυτήρ (kautḗr, “branding iron”), from καίειν (kaíein, “to burn”).

syn: fall in, be in sympathy, be in harmony, be in accord, be in agreement, be in accordance, go along, accord
etym: Borrowed from Latin concurro (“to run together, agree”).

syn: eccentricity, quirk, crotchet, idiosyncrasy, mannerism, whimsy, fad, vagary, foible, twist, oddity, whim, caprice
etym: First attested in 1604, in modern sense since 1665, from Old French idiosyncrasie, from Ancient Greek ἰδιοσυγκρασία (idiosunkrasía, “one’s own temperament”), from ἴδιος (ídios, “one’s own”) + σύν (sún, “together”) + κρᾶσις (krâsis, “temperament”).

syn: meter, measure, measuring device
etym: The original meaning was 'sundial' and/or 'clock dial'; from Middle English diall, from Middle French dyal, from Latin diālis (“daily, concerning the day”), because of its use in telling the time of day, from Latin diēs (“day”). Compare Spanish dial and día (“day”).

zh_Hans: 无名的；鲜为人知的；默默无闻的
syn: unknown, doubtful, mysterious, concealed, indeterminate, dubious, hazy, uncertain, in doubt, hidden, vague
etym: From Old French obscur, from Latin obscūrus (“dark, dusky, indistinct”), possibly, from ob (“over”) + -scurus (“covered”), from root scu (“cover”), seen also in scutum (“a shield”); see scutum, sky.

zh_Hans: 目光敏锐的；洞察力强的
syn: responsive, sharp-sighted, far-seeing, understanding, sensible, sage, discerning, penetrating, quick, intelligent, acute, intuitive, far-sighted, wise, sensitive, clear-eyed, open-eyed, sharp-witted, discriminating, canny, clever, perspicacious, shrewd, sharp, clear-sighted, alert, sagacious, judicious, perceptive, incisive
etym: From Latin percipiēns, present participle of percipiō (“to perceive”).

zh_Hans: （尤指失败或错误引起的）失望，懊丧，懊恼
syn: fury, rage, crossness, vexation, displeasure, exasperation, anger, spleen, wrath, pique, irritation
etym: From French chagrin (“sorrow”), from Middle French chagrin (“pain, affliction”) (compare Middle French chagriner, chagrigner (“to experience sorrow”), Old French chagrin (“painful, afflicted”)), probably derived from Old Northern French chagreiner, chagraigner (“to sadden”)[1], of uncertain origin. Likely an enlargement of Old French greignier, graignier (“to cringe, growl, be sullen, be angry, grieve over”)[2], from Old French graigne (“sadness, resentment, grief”), from graim (“sorrowful”), related to Old High German gram (“furious, gloomy, grieved”)[3]. The initial syllable is obscure. It may represent Old French chat (“cat”) to express the idea of "lamenting or yowling like cats" (compare German Katzenjammer (“distress, frustration, depression, chagrin”, literally “cat-wailing, cat-misery”), katzbalgen (“to cat-fight”))[4].

zh_Hans: 自命不凡的，自大的；装模作样的
syn: premonitory, fateful, predictive, foreshadowing, warning, momentous, prognosticatory
etym: Borrowed from Latin portentōsus, from portentus; equivalent to portent +‎ -ous.
anthropo- +‎ -centric.

zh_Hans: （人）贪赃的，腐败的，见利忘义的
syn: purchasable, corruptible, bribable, open to bribery, buyable, grafting

ant: , patient, stoic, stoical, phlegmatic, happy    [WS], impassive, uncomplaining, tolerant, unflappable, calm    [WS], unpeevish, expressionless
syn: morose, peppery, grumpy, sulky, curmudgeonly, disagreeable, impatient, sooky (Aus, fretful, gripeful, peevish, carping, kvetchy, grouchy, crabby, plaintful, querulous, cantankerous, grumbling, grotchy (fandom slang), whining, on edge, pettish, fractious, irascible, Canada), crotchety, moaning, bemoaning, petulant, gripey, NZ, edgy, crabbed, miserable, complaining, knappish (obsolete), noodgy, spleeny, cross, mardy (UK), whiny, whingy
etym: From Middle English pevische, pevisse, pevysse, peivesshe, also peyuesshe, peeuish, of obscure origin. Perhaps from Middle English pew, pue (“a plaintive cry, the cry of a bird”), equivalent to pue +‎ -ish. Cognate with Scots pevis, pevess, pevych, pevach (“peevish”), Scots pew, peu (“to cry in a plaintive manner”). See pue.
hypo: —, pettifoging, hypochondriacal, critical, captious, faultfinding, hypercritical, caviling, nitpicky, vapourish, fastidious    [WS]

syn: placate, conciliate, appease, mollify, pacify
etym: From Latin dulcificāre.

zh_Hans: 死尸般的；惨白的；形容枯槁的
syn: bloodless, waxy, deathlike, ghostly, waxen, pallid, corpse-like, ashen-faced, cadaverous, ashen, unburied, white, chalky, chalk white, grey, ashy, white-faced, whey-faced, deathly pale
etym: cadaver +‎ -ous
hypo: deathlike, raw-boned, drawn, waxy, waxen, sluggish, hollow-cheeked, etiolated, hollow-eyed, anemic, scrawny    [WS], ghostly    [WS], gaunt, skeletal, bony, lymphatic, pallid    [WS], spindle-shanked, feeble, haggard, pinched

zh_Hans: 武断的；自以为是的；教条的
syn: unyielding, uncompromising, peremptory, imperative, adamant, entrenched, authoritarian, doctrinaire, rigid, dictatorial, insistent, imperious, assertive, pontifical, unquestionable, unchallengeable, overbearing, authoritative, domineering, arrogant, high-handed, inflexible, unbending, emphatic
etym: From French dogmatique, from Late Latin dogmaticus, from Hellenistic Ancient Greek δογματικός (dogmatikós, “didactic”), from δόγμα (dógma, “dogma”).

zh_Hans: 不容置疑地;毫无疑问地
etym: indubitable +‎ -ly

syn: plague, scourge, infestation
etym: From French épidémique, from épidémie, from Latin epidemia, from Ancient Greek ἐπιδήμιος (epidḗmios), from ἐπί (epí, “upon”) + δῆμος (dêmos, “people”).

syn: pretender, pietist, whited sepulchre, deceiver, dissembler, humbug, impostor, plaster saint
etym: Old French ypocrite (Modern French hypocrite), from Ecclesiastical Latin hypocrita, from Ancient Greek ὑποκριτής (hupokritḗs, “actor, hypocrite”), from ὑποκρίνομαι (hupokrínomai, “I answer, act, feign”).

zh_Hans: 为两党派所支持的；包括两个党派的
etym: From bi- +‎ partisan.

zh_Hans: 公开放弃，声明放弃（信念、行为、活动）
syn: disclaim, repudiate, abandon, relinquish, spurn, reject, abnegate, drop, dispense with, gainsay, do away with, forswear, forgo, disavow, wash one's hands of, deny, give up
etym: From Middle English abjuren, from Latin abiūrō (“deny upon oath”) (possibly via Middle French abjurer), formed from ab (“from, away from”) + iūro (“swear or take an oath”), from iūs (“law, right, duty”).[1]

zh_Hans: 使回忆起(人或事);回忆过去的;怀旧的;缅怀往事的
syn: bearing comparison with, tending to make one think of, comparable with, inviting comparison with
etym: From Latin reminīscēns, present participle of reminīscor (“remember”), from re- (“again”) + min-, base of me-min-isse (“to remember, think over”), akin to mens (“mind”); see mental, mind, etc.

syn: predate, be earlier than, anticipate, come before, go before
etym: ante- +‎ date

zh_Hans: （疾病）大规模流行的，广泛蔓延的
syn: pandemic, prevalent, rife, rampant, epidemic, pervasive
etym: From Late Latin pandēmus (“affecting all the people, public, general”), from Ancient Greek πᾶν (pân, “all”) (equivalent to English pan-) + δῆμος (dêmos, “the people”).

zh_Hans: 情感异常强烈的;激昂的;充满激情的
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：ferv 沸腾；发热 + id 有…性质的 → 热情的，热烈的
syn: emotional, sincere, ardent, fervid, profound, passionate, heartfelt, animated, vehement, feeling, spirited, deeply felt, deep-seated, intense
etym: Borrowed from Latin fervidus, from ferveō.

zh_Hans: 扰嚷;(表示抗议,支持等的)叫喊
etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：clam 呼喊，叫喊 + or 表情况 → 喧哗，吵闹
syn: screaming, loud noise, blaring, shouting, racket, yelling, babel, baying, uproar, clangour, roaring, tumult
etym: Recorded in English since c. 1385, from Old French clamor (modern clameur), from Latin clāmor (“a shout, cry”), from clāmō (“cry out, complain”); the sense to silence may have a distinct (unknown) etymology.
From Latin centrum (“center”) + fugiō (“to flee”)  +‎ -al, probably coined by Christiaan Huygens.

etym_zh_Hans: 记忆技巧：umbr 影子 + age 表状态 → 树荫；不快〔心中有影子〕
syn: get into a huff, be offended, get one's hackles up, be indignant, be angry, be aggrieved, be insulted, be piqued, take something amiss, be put out, be upset, be resentful, take exception, be disgruntled, go into a huff, take something personally, be wounded, be affronted, be hurt, be annoyed, bridle, get huffy
etym: Borrowed from Middle French ombrage (“umbrage”), from Old French ombrage, from Latin umbrāticus (“in the shade”), from umbra (“shadow, shade”).

syn: , anthropology
etym: From New Latin anthropologia, from anthropo- (from Ancient Greek ἄνθρωπος (ánthrōpos, “man, mankind, human, humanity”)) + -logy (from Ancient Greek -λογία (-logía)).

zh_Hans: （常指结伴同行的）远足，短程旅行
syn: journey, jaunt, expedition, tour, outing
etym: Borrowed from Latin excursio (“a running out, an inroad, invasion, a setting out, beginning of a speech”), from excurrere (“to run out”), from ex (“out”) + currere (“to run”).

zh_Hans: （尤指国家的）霸权，支配权，领导权
syn: control, dominion, supremacy, dominance, primacy, sway, ascendancy, authority, predominance, power, sovereignty, rule, mastery
etym: From Ancient Greek ἡγεμονία (hēgemonía, “supremacy or leadership, chief command”), from ἡγεμών (hēgemṓn, “a leader, guide, commander, chief”), from ἡγέομαι (hēgéomai, “to lead”).

ko: …에 언짢은 표정을 짓다, 무안을 주다; …에 찬성하지 않다, …을 승인하지 않다
syn: frown on, find unacceptable, object to, think wrong, not believe in, take a dim view of, be against
etym: From Middle French descontenancer (compare French décontenancer).

zh_Hans: （尤指因为某人没成功或没达到预期目标而）责备，责怪，批评

etym: Old French reprochier (Modern reprocher).

zh_Hans: 当地的；本土的，土生土长的
syn: aboriginal, local
etym: Borrowed from Late Latin indigenus (“native, born in a country”), from indi- (indu-), an old derivative of in (“in”), gen- the root of gignō (“give birth to”), and English -ous. Compare indigene, Ancient Greek ἐνδογενής (endogenḗs, “born in the house”), and the separately formed endogenous.

syn: peppery, snappish, moody, grumpy, waspish, dyspeptic, raspy, as cross as two sticks, stressy, curmudgeonly, ratty (British), in a bad mood, bilious, disagreeable, shrewish, quick-tempered, crusty, snippety, fretful, twitchy (figurative), irritable, peevish, carnaptious (UK dialect, Ireland), snippish, humpy, grouchy, cross-grained, crabby, touchy, scratchy, querulous, cantankerous, ill-natured, hot-tempered, grotchy (fandom slang), huffy, thorny, out of sorts, in a mood, hot-livered (archaic), prickly, ill-humoured, tetty (obsolete), liverish, pettish, fractious, thin-skinned, irascible, choleric, crotchety, testy, snitchy, having got out of bed on the wrong side, petulant, bad-tempered, splenetic, ill-tempered, crabbed, edgy (dated), short-tempered, umbrageous (figurative), bitchy (vulgar, peevish    [WS], tetchy, cross, atrabilious, snappy, colloquial), snippy, cranky

var: like a bear with a sore head, on edge

syn: self-contradictory, inconsistent, anomalous, conflicting, incongruous
etym: paradox +‎ -ical

syn: tired, ordinary, stereotyped, predictable, stock, pedestrian, routine, hoary, overused, run-of-the-mill, prosaic, commonplace, hack, vapid, worn out, stale, unimaginative, threadbare, clichéd, overdone, dull, unoriginal, boring, platitudinous, common, derivative, time-worn, uninspired, overworked, conventional, hackneyed, humdrum
etym: Borrowed from French banal, from Medieval Latin bannalis (“pertaining to compulsory feudal service, applied especially to mills, wells, ovens, etc., used in common by people of the lower classes, upon the command of a feudal superior; hence, common, commonplace”), from bannum (“command, proclamation”). See also ban, abandon.

syn: wayfaring, wandering, nomadic, touring, rambling, ambulatory, migratory, roaming, gypsy, peripatetic, migrant, roving
etym: From Late Latin itinerāntem, from itinerāns, present active participle of itineror (“I travel”). See also itinerate, itinerary.

syn: scattered, irregular, isolated, fitful, broken, spasmodic, odd, random, discontinuous, disconnected, patchy, fragmentary
etym: From Middle French intermittent, from Latin intermittens (“sending between”), from prefix inter- (“among, on”), plus present participle mittens (“sending”), from mittere (“to send”).

zh_Hans: 屈从，屈服；放弃抵抗；承认失败
syn: capitulate, submit, give in, give way, cave in, surrender
etym: From Old French succomber, from Latin succumbō.

syn: rage, declaim, remonstrate, storm, protest, rail
etym: From Latin invehō (“bring in, carry in”), from in- + vehō (“carry”). Compare vehicle, invective.

ko: (큰 방 한 쪽을 칸막이 해 만든) 좁은 방
zh_Hans: （大房间中分隔出来的）小房间，小隔间
syn: prison, lock-up, oubliette
etym: Borrowed from Latin cubiculum (“bedroom”), from cubō (“lie down”). Doublet of cubiculum, an unadapted borrowing.

syn: visage, dated), pan (slang), favor (obsolete), George Best (Cockney rhyming slang), phiz (dated), boat (Cockney rhyming slang), dial, punim, profile, mush (UK, slang), face, countenance, phizog (dated), look    [WS] (often plural), complexion, map (UK, eek (Polari), ecaf (Backslang), mug (slang), physiognomy, Chevy Chase (Cockney rhyming slang), kisser (slang), features

etym: Borrowed from French faux pas (“faux pas, blunder; misstep, false step”), from faux (“false, wrong”) and pas (“step”).
See altruism.

syn: baked, parched, scorched, waterless, moistureless, as dry as a bone, thirsty, dried up
etym: Ultimately from the Latin term āridus (“dry, arid, parched”), confer its synonymous contracted form ardus. Originally from the verb āreo (“I am dry, I am parched”), akin to ārdeō (“I am on fire, I burn”).
From Ancient Greek χρωματικός (khrōmatikós), from χρῶμα (khrôma, “colour”).

zh_Hans: 可共存的；协调的；相容的
syn: suited, reconcilable, in harmony, in tune, well matched, of the same mind, in agreement, like-minded
etym: from Middle French compatible, from Medieval Latin compatibilis (“in compatible beneficium, a benefice which could be held together with another one”), from Late Latin compati (“to suffer with”)

syn: raze, level, bring down, tear down, hack down, chop down, hew, knock down, clear, demolish, saw down
etym: From Proto-Albanian *spesla, metathesized form of *spelsa, from Proto-Indo-European *pels (“rock, boulder”), variant of *spel- (“to cleave, break”). Compare Latin hydronym Pelso, Latin Palatium, Pashto پرښه‎ (parša, “rock, rocky ledge”), Ancient Greek πέλλα (pélla, “stone”), German Felsen (“boulder, cliff”). Mostly dialectal, used in Gheg Albanian.

Old French synagoge, from Ancient Greek συναγωγή (sunagōgḗ, “assembly, gathering”), from συνάγω (sunágō, “I gather together”), from σύν (sún, “with, together”) + ἄγω (ágō, “I lead”)

Originally, perhaps expressive in origin from la-la-la or lu-lu-lu sounds made in calming a child.
